topics.body:
!http://cdn.theatlantic.com/newsroom/img/posts/RTX12B04.jpg!
In-vitro meat could be made to contain no saturated fats, heme iron (which could actually raise risk of heart disease) or growth hormone. It would also be far less likely to cause toxoplasmosis or mad cow disease. It currently has different ranges of nutrition to normal meat, but scientists are working to change that. If anything, it is BETTER than conventional meat.

topics.body:
"@Whatevs":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/538a95436368724ebd480500#post_538a95436368724ebd480500
Our bodies are not made for this. We have been eating real meat for thousands of years and all of a sudden we have to eat this fake stuff that the body can't recognize. Sure it may be similar to meat but it's not meat.
topics.author: 5010fa077f123b1e4f00104e

topics.body:
"@someguy111":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/538a95c86368724eeb430400#post_538a95c86368724eeb430400
You won't have a choice in the matter.  In ten years time synthesized food will have in all probability replaced natural food because farms and ranches will no longer be able to compete thus being forced out of business.  So in all reality your *ONLY* choices would be to eat the synthesized food, pay $1000 per steak, have your own farm or starve to death.  Also I have had a sustenance farm before, and I know how back breaking it is, anyone that says they're going to grow their own food speaking from personal experience is a outright liar.  I have had my own farm before; so yeah I'm going to have to call bullshit on anyone that says they're going to grow all their own food.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/538a96c96368724c61570500#post_538a96c96368724c61570500
I think 10 years is too soon for anything like that to happen.
topics.author: 5010fa077f123b1e4f00104e

topics.body:
"@someguy111":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/538a974a6368724ed77e0500#post_538a974a6368724ed77e0500
The reason why right now we don't have synthesized food is that if it were to go into mass production right now it would cost twice as much.  The reason why it's still in the engineering phase is they're trying to figure out how to cut costs.

Also keep in mind that ten years ago we were still using vcr tapes, blockbuster was still around, no one had texting cell phones, people still had to go to movie theatres to watch movies, internet television was a pipe dream, people still read the newspaper and people still used pagers.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/538a97e86368724ebd880600#post_538a97e86368724ebd880600
Cutting costs usually means cutting corners making an already undesirable product even worse because they use cheap and inferior ingredients and/or methods to make it.

It would also be far less likely to cause toxoplasmosis or mad cow disease. It currently has different ranges of nutrition to normal meat, but scientists are working to change that. If anything, it is BETTER than conventional meat.[/bq]
I actually find this to be pretty cool, scientifically.
